[[West Virginia Intercollegiate Athletic Conference|WVIAC]] |website=[http://www.upj.pitt.edu/ www.upj.pitt.edu/] |logo = |footnotes = }} '''University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown''', also known as '''UPJ''' or '''Pitt-Johnstown''', is a four-year, degree-granting regional campus of the [[University of Pittsburgh]]. The university is located in [[Richland Township, Cambria County, Pennsylvania|Richland Township]], a suburban area of [[Johnstown, Pennsylvania|Johnstown]], [[Pennsylvania]] and was founded in 1927 as one of the first regional campuses of a major [[university]] in the [[United States]]. UPJ is ranked as the 28th best baccalaureate college in the North and the eighth best public baccalaureate college in the North by ''U.S. News & World Report'' in its "America's Best Colleges 2010" annual college guide.{{cite web | url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/johnstown-pa/university-of-pittsburgh-johnstown-3382 | year=2009 | title=US News & World Report: Best Colleges: University of Pittsburgh--Johnstown | publisher=U.S. News & World Report | accessdate=2009-08-21}} UPJ is also listed among the "Best Colleges in the Northeastern Region" by The Princeton Review.{{cite web | url=http://www.princetonreview.com/UniversityofPittsburghatJohnstown.aspx | title=The Princeton Review: University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown | publisher=The Princeton Review | accessdate=2009-08-21}} ==History== UPJ was founded in 1927 as a two-year college of the University of Pittsburgh. For almost 20 years it held classes in the Johnstown High School building in the Kernville section of downtown Johnstown. After World War II, the Johnstown College moved to the Moxham section of town where the number of courses and students increased. In the early 1960s, community leaders worked with the University of Pittsburgh to build a new campus in [[Richland Township, Cambria County, Pennsylvania|Richland Township]], a Johnstown suburb. The new campus opened in 1967 with two classroom buildings, five dormitories, and a student union. Degree-granting status was awarded to UPJ by the University of Pittsburgh in 1970. The campus has grown significantly since that time, with five academic buildings, a library, an expanded student union, a sports and aquatic center, a conference center, a chapel, a performing arts center, and a large cluster of dormitories, lodges, townhouse apartments and other student residence housing. UPJ now offers over 40 baccalaureate and associate degree programs. ==Academics== [[File:UPJBlackingtonCat.jpg|thumb|left|225px|The Mountain Cat statue outside of Blackington Hall]] UPJ offers a Bachelor of Arts and a Bachelor of Science degree in more than 40 areas. Additionally, UPJ offers several associate degrees in the allied health area. The college offers more than 40 academic majors, with minors available in most of the major fields, as well as in other areas of arts and sciences. The average class size is 25â30, and the student to teacher ratio is 19:1. The college is strictly undergraduate, and all courses are taught by college faculty. The 149 faculty members have outstanding credentials and remain active professionally. Special opportunities include internships, the Presidentâs Scholars program, independent and directed studies, a self-designed major, the Freshman Seminar Series, an International Studies Certificate, and the Academic Success Center. UPJ operates on a modified trimester calendar. The standard school year includes a 15-week fall term (September to mid-December) and a 15-week spring term (January to mid-April). Optional summer term offerings from 5-week to 15-week sessions allow students to accelerate their degrees. The University of Pittsburgh, including UPJ and other regional campuses, is accredited by the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]] and by the [[Middle_States_Association_of_Colleges_and_Schools#Commission_on_Higher_Education|Commission on Higher Education]]. The engineering technology programs at Johnstown are accredited by the Technology Accreditation Commission of the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology Inc. ==Campus and facilities== [[File:OwenLibrary.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Owen Library]] The Johnstown campus is situated in a suburban, wooded setting occupying {{convert|650|acre|km2}} which makes UPJ physically the third largest campus in Pennsylvania. It is located eight miles (13 km) outside Johnstown, Pennsylvania (metropolitan population of 110,000); {{convert|70|mi|km}} east of Pittsburgh; and {{convert|175|mi|km}} north of Washington, D.C. The 32 campus buildings, mostly in [[freestone]] masonry, include resident housing, classroom buildings, a performing arts center, sports center, library, student union, and outdoor recreation areas. Other features include a {{convert|40|acre|m2|adj=on}} nature preserve, more than 15 intramural activities, more than 70 student organizations, and NCAA Division II menâs and womenâs sports. The campus has five academic/administrative buildings: Biddle Hall, Krebs Hall, Engineering and Science Building, Blackington Administrative Classroom Building, and the Living/Learning Center. Each building contains classrooms, laboratories, faculty offices, and/or administrative offices. Additional facilities include a music room, greenhouse, computer rooms, auditoriums, an audio-visual classroom, and conference rooms. Also available to students is the advanced technology classroom (ATC) in Biddle Hall. The room is designed for electronic distance learning. It is equipped with satellite down-link programming, three full-motion cameras, data ports, video monitors, and much more. It is currently one of the most sophisticated ATCs in operation at any college or university in Pennsylvania. The Owen Library holds more than 146,086 bound volumes, 15,358 titles on microfilm, 625 periodical subscriptions, approximately 130 online subscription databases, and more than 4,500 electronic journals. All students have additional access to many additional libraries on Pittâs other campuses. [[File:PasqPerfArtC.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Pasquerilla Performing Arts Center]]]] Campus-wide computing labs for student use are available. Labs primarily contain Windows 7-based PCs, along with several Macintosh computers, application servers, laser printers, scanners, and advanced graphics devices. The labs can be used to work with software, such as word processing and programming languages, or to access network services, such as online card catalogs, electronic mail, and the Internet. There are more than 150 computers available on campus for student use. The Student Union, located in the middle of campus, houses the Student Life Office, Health Services, Residence Services, Career Services, Campus Ministry, and the Bookstore/convenience store. Also included are a full-service mail room, a 400-person cafeteria, a fast food shop, and a nonalcoholic pub. The union also holds a game room, information desk, and many organizational offices. A recent renovation created a bistro-style restaurant, named the Mountain Cat Club, as a dining option for students. Located directly outside of the cafeteria, the club features flat screen televisions, a dance floor, and a stage in order to provide an additional area for student programing.[http://www.upjadvocate.com/index.php?action=article&sid=2&aid=230 Jonathan Weaver, Sports bar soon to take place of banquet hall, The Advocate, 2009-02-04, accessdate=2009-02-19]{{cite newspaper | url=http://mac10.umc.pitt.edu/u/FMPro?-db=ustory&-lay=a&-format=d.html&storyid=8825&-Find | title=What's New? Places | last=Hart | first=Peter | last2=Barlow | first2=Kimberly K. | newspaper=University Times | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=2009-09-03 | accessdate=2009-09-08}} The [[Pasquerilla Performing Arts Center]] (PPAC) is a {{convert|42000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} multipurpose facility; it was completed in 1991. It contains a 1,000-seat concert hall, a 200-seat black box theater, and supporting operational spaces. Performances include UPJ Department of Theatre Arts shows and Broadway productions. The PPAC is also home to the Johnstown Symphony Orchestra and the Southern Alleghenies Museum of Art at Johnstown. The art gallery displays at least eight exhibitions a year as well as work produced by UPJ students. [[File:UPJResidenceHall.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Willow Hall student residence]] The J. Irving Whalley Memorial Chapel was constructed in 1991 as well. It is nondenominational and seats 250 people. Weekly Catholic mass and Protestant services are held, as well as personal conferences. The Sports Center and Zamias Aquatic Center provide recreational facilities for more than 15 intramural sports, as well as intercollegiate activities. The building houses a {{convert|25|yd|sing=on}} indoor swimming pool, a workout room with free weights, an aerobic/dance studio, and locker rooms with showers. On January 5, 2011, the university opened the $9.7 million {{convert|40000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} Wellness Center which is adjacent to the Sports Center The Wellness Center features a three-lane elevated running track, cardiovascular and strength-training equipment, dance/exercise/classroom space, two multipurpose courts for basketball and volleyball, an indoor climbing wall, as well as an outdoor wellness park.{{cite newspaper | url=http://www.tribune-democrat.com/local/local_story_304003316.html | first=Mike | last=Faher | date=2009-11-01 | newspaper=The Tribune Democrat | location=Johnstown, PA | accessdate=2009-11-13}}{{cite newspaper | url=http://www.dailyamerican.com/articles/2009/11/05/news/local/news166.txt | title= UPJ to break ground on new wellness center | date=2009-11-04 | newspaper=The Daily American | location=Somerset, PA | accessdate=2009-12-13}} An approximately $10 million {{convert|20000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} nursing and health science facility is planned to begin construction in 2010.{{cite newspaper | url= http://www.utimes.pitt.edu/?p=10808 | title=Trustees approve capital budget | first=Kimberly K. | last=Barlow | date=2010-01-07 | newspaper=University Times | Volume=42 | issue=9 | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | accessdate=2010-01-11}} ===Student residences=== The Living/Learning Center, completed in 1994, is a 400-person residence unit, which includes a full-circuit weight training room, sauna, an aerobics room, and a smaller student cafeteria. The Living/Learning Center is not only used as a residence but also as a conference center throughout the year. With several meeting rooms, the facility can accommodate groups of 20â250 people. [[File:Pittsburgh johnstown logo.png|right|thumb|The UPJ logo featuring the Mountain Cat]] In addition to the residence units in the Living/Learning Center, the campus offers the choice of single-sex and coeducational housing. There are 5 freshman residence halls, one upper class residence hall, seven small-group lodges, 46 townhouse-style apartment units, and an apartment complex. ==Athletics== [[File:UPJbasketball2010 2.jpg|thumb|right|UPJ men's basketball game in 2010]] Pitt Johnstown is a [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] member of the [[National Collegiate Athletics Association]] (NCAA), as well as a member of the [[West Virginia Intercollegiate Athletic Conference]] (WVIAC). Twelve varsity men's and women's sports are offered including women's [[volleyball]], menâs and womenâs [[college soccer|soccer]], menâs and womenâs [[golf]], menâs and womenâs [[college basketball|basketball]], [[collegiate wrestling|wrestling]], womenâs indoor and outdoor [[track and field]], and [[college baseball|baseball]].[http://www.upj.pitt.edu/18154/ University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown: Athletics Mission Statement, accessdate=2009-03-28] Perhaps the most prominent sport at UPJ is wrestling, which has had several top national finishes and won the Division II National Championships in 1996 and 1999.[http://campus.mst.edu/athleticsarchives/ncaachamps.html NCAA Division II National Champions, accessdate=2009-03-28] The wrestling program also includes several highly decorated wrestlers among its former athletes, including the most decorated wrestler in NCAA history, [[Carlton Haselrig]], who went undefeated during his career and won three [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] and three Division II individual national championships.{{cite press release | last = Caputo | first =Chris | title = Six Selected for Induction into Pitt Johnstown Athletics Hall of Fame on April 4, 2009 | publisher = University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown Department of Athletics | date = 2008-12-10 | url = http://www.upj.pitt.edu/19552.pdf | accessdate = 2009-03-28}} Men's Basketball is also successful and has advanced to four [[NCAA Men's Division II Basketball Championship|NCAA Men's Division II Basketball Tournaments]], including appearances in the tournament in 2008 and 2009.{{cite press release | title = Mountain Cats Earn Second Straight NCAA Tournament Bid; Pitt-Johnstown to Play Top-Seeded Gannon University | publisher = University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown Department of Athletics | date = 2009-03-08 | url = http://www.upj.pitt.edu/3796/ | accessdate = 2009-03-28}} The men's basketball team has appeared in the Division II national rankings several times, and finished as high as fifth in the nation in 1999.[http://campus.mst.edu/athleticsarchives/hoops/d2basketball/ncaa2mbbpolls.pdf History of NCAA Division II Basketball Rankings: 1961-2008, pg.47 & 153, date=2008-05-23, accessdate=2009-03-28] Women's basketball at UPJ has appeared in 13 Division II and 3 Division III NCAA tournaments, including the 1987 Division II Final Four.[http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/w_basketball_champs_records/2008/d2/2009champs.pdf 2009 NCAA Women's Division II Championship Records, pg. 19, accessdate=2009-04-26][http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/w_basketball_champs_records/2008/d3/2009champs.pdf 2009 NCAA Women's Division III Championship Records, pg. 27, accessdate=2009-04-26] The baseball team plays some of its home games at [[Point Stadium#Current stadium|Point Stadium]]. The baseball program participated in the NCAA North Atlantic Regional Tournament in the 2006, and 2008 seasons. ==References== [[File:UPJHickoryHall.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Hickory Hall]] [[File:UPJEngineerSci.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Engineering and Science Building]] {{reflist}} ==Further reading== {{cite book | first=Robert J. | last=Hunter | title=The Evolution of a College: a History of the University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown (1927-1993) | year=1996? | publisher=University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown | location=Johnstown, PA}} ==External links== {{Portal|PITT|break=yes}} *[http://www.upj.pitt.edu/ Official Website] *[http://www.upj.pitt.edu/277/ UPJ Arts - Pasquerilla Performing Arts Center] ==Campus gallery== File:UPJBlackingtonInter.jpg|Interior lobby of Blackington Hall File:UPJLivingLearningC.jpg|Living/Learning Center (LLC) File:UPJMapleHall.jpg|Maple Hall File:UPJStudUn.jpg|Student Union File:PasqPerfArtCenter.jpg|[[Pasquerilla Performing Arts Center]] File:PasqPerfArtC2.jpg|Interior of the Pasquerilla Performing Arts Center {{University of Pittsburgh}} {{West Virginia Intercollegiate Athletic Conference}} {{Johnstown, Pennsylvania}} {{coord|40.267507|N|78.834913|W |format=dms |region:US_type:edu |display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pittsburgh at Johnstown, University of}} [[Category:University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown| ]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American Association of State Colleges and Universities]] [[Category:Johnstown, Pennsylvania|University]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1927]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Cambria County, Pennsylvania]] [[es:Universidad de Pittsburgh en Johnstown]]
